Transfer back of sale proceeds to buyer of home by debtor. - Where a Chapter 7 debtor received net proceeds from the sale of her home to her sister-in-law and gave the funds back to the sister-in-law two weeks later, the transfer was avoidable under § 55-81 and 11 U.S.C.S. § 544(b)(1) because it was for no valuable consideration, at a time when the debtor was insolvent, and depleted the bankruptcy estate of a valuable cash asset. Phillips v. Moazzeni (In re Tarangelo), 378 Bankr. 128, 2007 Bankr. LEXIS 3343 (Bankr. E.D. Va. 2007).

A gift of a chattel, being without valuable consideration, is always void as to existing creditors of the donor; but as to subsequent creditors actual fraud must be proved. Morrisette v. Cook & Bernheimer Co., 122 Va. 588, 95 S.E. 449 (1918).

Authorization for equitable lien found. - Under voluntary conveyance statute, where Chapter 7 debtor paid off mortgage note with nonexempt cash received by will, then transferred property to self and wife by tenancy by the entirety, trustee could set aside transfer and impose equitable lien on the property. Shaia v. Meyer, 206 Bankr. 410 (Bankr. E.D. Va. 1997).

Question of fact. - Bankruptcy court was unable to determine whether the companies were, as the debtor alleged, the entities for whose benefit the transfers were made as this was a question of fact and was not an issue that could be resolved on a Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss. Pathnet, Inc. v. Nortel Networks, Inc.(In re Pathnet, Inc.),, 2002 Bankr. LEXIS 1262 (Bankr. E.D. Va. Aug. 14, 2002).

Recorded deed of repurchase. - Where debtor purchased her residential real property from Habitat for Humanity subject to a limitation imposed by a recorded deed of repurchase, the court concluded that a hypothetical chapter 7 trustee would be bound by the deed of right to repurchase. The trustee could not avoid the recorded deed of repurchase under Virginia law. In re Plascencia, 354 Bankr. 774, 2006 Bankr. LEXIS 3066 (Bankr. E.D. Va. 2006).

F. EXISTING CREDITORS.

Who are existing creditors. - The word "creditors" as used in this section and § 55-80 includes all creditors, whether with or without notice. Davis v. Bonney, 89 Va. 755, 17 S.E. 229 (1893).

Holders of contingent claims are existing creditors. - Virginia follows the general rule that holders of contingent claims are "existing creditors" for purposes of avoiding a voluntary conveyance. Hyman v. Porter, 37 Bankr. 56 (Bankr. E.D. Va. 1984).

Where the principal shareholders exercised complete control over the affairs of a corporation and consequently transferred corporate assets to themselves in violation of § 55-80, the appropriate remedy in such a situation was to return the fraudulently conveyed assets for a ratable distribution to all legitimate creditors, which might include the recipient of the fraudulent conveyance and the principal shareholders, as legitimate creditors of the corporation were entitled to share in the distribution of the bankrupt's estate, after they returned the fraudulently conveyed assets, or their value, to the estate. APAC-Virginia, Inc. v. Jenkins Landscaping & Excavating, Inc., 93 Bankr. 84 (W.D. Va. 1988).

CIRCUIT COURT OPINIONS

Editor's note. - The cases cited below were decided under prior law.

Fraudulent conveyance. - Corporate director's and majority shareholder's act of directing the proceeds from the sale of corporate property to be made to them primarily, which was done while the corporation was insolvent and when the shareholder knew that it had at least two judgments against it, was a voluntary act made with the intent to hinder or defraud creditors; thus, such was voided as a fraudulent conveyance. Lawyers Title Ins. Corp. v. P.R.T. Enters., 65 Va. Cir. 271, 2004 Va. Cir. LEXIS 286 (Norfolk 2004).

Voluntary conveyance. - Judgment creditor proved its voluntary conveyance claim because transfers were made at a time when a seller and a purchaser were insolvent; the relevant individual transfer transactions lacked adequate consideration and were made at a time after the seller and purchaser were already indebted to the judgment creditor. Westwood Bldgs. Ltd. P'ship v. Grayson, 96 Va. Cir. 312, 2017 Va. Cir. LEXIS 166 (Fairfax County Sept. 8, 2017).

Burden of proof. - "Clear and convincing" standard seems to apply mostly to situations where the intent of a party might be in question, as opposed to mere evaluation of a fact that is objectively measurable; in the case of voluntary conveyance, the central operative fact is primarily a determination of "insolvency," which is generally of easy measurement, and the standard of proof for voluntary conveyance claims is thus by a preponderance of the evidence. Westwood Bldgs. Ltd. P'ship v. Grayson, 96 Va. Cir. 312, 2017 Va. Cir. LEXIS 166 (Fairfax County Sept. 8, 2017).

Proof of insolvency. - Although the Commonwealth failed to prove that a taxpayer was insolvent when the taxpayer transferred property to his girlfriend, the Commonwealth presented badges of fraud that the taxpayer did not rebut; therefore, the conveyance was fraudulent and void under § 55-80. Dep't of Taxation v. Nicolet, 62 Va. Cir. 372, 2003 Va. Cir. LEXIS 281 (Richmond 2003).

§ 55.1-402. Creditor's action to avoid such gifts, conveyances, assignments, transfers, or charges.

Before obtaining a judgment for his claim, a creditor may, whether such claim is due and payable or not, institute any action that he may institute after obtaining such judgment to avoid a gift, conveyance, assignment, or transfer of, or charge upon, the estate of his debtor declared void by either § 55.1-400 or 55.1-401. Such creditor may, in such action, have all the relief with respect to such estate to which he would be entitled after obtaining a judgment for the claim for which he may be entitled to recover. A creditor availing himself of this section shall have a lien from the time of bringing his action on all the estate, real and personal, and a petitioning creditor shall also be entitled to a lien from the time of filing his petition in the court in which the action is brought. If the proceeds of sale are insufficient to satisfy the claims of all the creditors whose liens were acquired at the same time, they shall be applied proportionately to such claims, and the court may issue an order against the debtor for any deficiency remaining on the claim of any creditor after applying his share of the proceeds of sale, or, if any creditor is not entitled to share in such proceeds, may issue an order against the debtor for the full amount of the creditor's claim. This section is subject to the provisions of §§ 8.01-268 and 8.01-269.

(Code 1919, § 5186; Code 1950, § 55-82; 1926, p. 874; 2009, c. 593; 2019, c. 712.)

Effective date. - This section is effective October 1, 2019.

Law review. - For article on fraudulent conveyances and preferences in Virginia, see 36 Wash. & Lee L. Rev. 51 (1979).

For annual survey essay, "Bulls, Bears, and Pigs: Revisiting the Legal Minefield of Virginia Fraudulent Transfer Law," see 46 U. Rich. L. Rev. 273 (2011).

Michie's Jurisprudence. - For related discussion, see 2A M.J. Assignments for the Benefit of Creditors, § 55; 2C M.J. Bankruptcy, §§ 106; 5A M.J. Creditors' Suits, §§ 10, 16; 9A M.J. Fraudulent and Voluntary Conveyances, §§ 43, 49, 70, 75, 76, 78, 80, 123; 12A M.J. Lis Pendens, § 3.

CASE NOTES

  • I. [Reserved.]
  • II. Decided Under Prior Law.
I. [RESERVED.]
II. DECIDED UNDER PRIOR LAW.

Creditor may sue under this section without first obtaining judgment. - As the law was before this section a creditor could not attack a conveyance for fraud without first obtaining a judgment or decree against his debtor. This section, which originated in the Code of 1849, changed this rule and authorized a creditor at large to institute such a suit without first obtaining judgment. Wallace's Adm'r v. Treakle, 68 Va. (27 Gratt.) 479 (1876); Johnston v. Straus, 26 F. 57 (E.D. Va. 1882); Trimble v. Covington Grocery Co., 112 Va. 826, 72 S.E. 724 (1911); Wood v. Lester, 126 Va. 169, 101 S.E. 52 (1919).

This section allows a bill to be filed by a creditor to set aside a conveyance, etc., declared void by §§ 55-80 and 55-81, before obtaining judgment or decree, upon the ground that the above sections refer to fraudulent acts that are void. Brown v. Putney, 90 Va. 447, 18 S.E. 883 (1894).

The lien given by this section is a lien only upon the property conveyed, and not, like the lien of a judgment, on all of a debtor's estate. Davis v. Bonney, 89 Va. 755, 17 S.E. 229 (1893).

It is inchoate until conveyance is adjudged void. - This section was intended to benefit those creditors who, by their diligence, succeed in bringing into court for distribution a fund, or assets placed beyond the reach of the unsecured creditors by the fraudulent or voluntary act of the debtor, and such creditors as attack the fraudulent or voluntary act and succeed in subjecting such fund or assets. But the lien provided for is never perfected unless and until the deed or other act of the debtor attacked is adjudicated to be fraudulent and void. If there is no such adjudication, the lien is inchoate and ineffectual. Quinn-Marshall Co. v. Whittaker, 116 Va. 965, 83 S.E. 398 (1914). See Wood v. Lester, 126 Va. 169, 101 S.E. 52 (1919).

And it may be waived. - The lien given by this section may be waived by the subsequent contracts and dealings of the creditor with the debtor. Quinn-Marshall Co. v. Whittaker, 116 Va. 965, 83 S.E. 398 (1914).

Creditor may not be substituted to position of fraudulent grantee. - A creditor who successfully assails a deed of trust on the ground that it secures a fraudulent debt is not entitled to be substituted to the position formerly occupied by the fraudulent creditor. His lien, if not previously acquired, dates only from the commencement of his suit, and is subordinate to liens previously acquired. The deed is valid as to bona fide debts, and the fraudulent debt is eliminated. Craig v. Hoge, 95 Va. 275, 28 S.E. 317 (1897).

Parties are placed in same position as if conveyance had never been made. - The result of setting aside a conveyance, under this section, is to place the parties in the same situation as if the conveyance had never been made, and to subject the property to the payment of the creditors of the grantor. Ferguson & Co. v. Daughtrey, 94 Va. 308, 26 S.E. 822 (1897).

Provision as to personal decree to be liberally construed. - If from any cause the result of the suit prove unavailing to any creditor united therein, the court may render a personal decree against the debtor for the amount of the creditor's claim. This feature of this section is remedial and should be liberally construed, especially as this construction accomplishes the wise end of preventing a multiplicity of suits, terminates litigation, and does no substantial injury to the debtor. Battle v. Rock, 144 Va. 1, 131 S.E. 344 (1926).

Service of attachment does not create debtor-creditor relation. - The service of an attachment upon a garnishee did not create the relation of debtor and creditor between the garnishee and the attaching creditor, within the meaning of this section and former § 55-83, and did not confer upon such attaching creditor the right to avoid a sale in gross of merchandise by said garnishee for want of conformity to former § 55-83. Trimble v. Covington Grocery Co., 112 Va. 826, 72 S.E. 724 (1911).

The filing of a homestead deed is not a conveyance which can be attacked under this section. Simon v. Ellison, 2 Va. Dec. 203, 22 S.E. 860 (1895).

No lis pendens without interest in property. - Pursuant to § 55-82, as limited by subsection B of § 8.01-268, a plaintiff in an action claiming fraudulent conveyance as to a specific property is not free to file a memorandum of lis pendens on property in which he does not assert or claim an interest. Meliani v. Jade Dunn Loring Metro, L.L.C., 286 F. Supp. 2d 741, 2003 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 18178 (E.D. Va. 2003).

Condominium project owner's motion to quash a lis pendens in a condominium purchaser's breach of contract and fraud action was granted; because the purchaser neither contracted to purchase a unit in the other three phases, nor obtained a lien on the phases under § 55-82, it followed that the purchaser could not establish an interest in, or file a memorandum of lis pendens on, the three phases. Meliani v. Jade Dunn Loring Metro, L.L.C., 286 F. Supp. 2d 741, 2003 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 18178 (E.D. Va. 2003).

Interlocutory decree as res judicata. - In a suit under this section to set aside a deed of trust as fraudulent, decrees, the first of which established appellant's claim as a lien upon the property and referred the cause to a commissioner to take account of liens, and the second of which confirmed the report of the commissioner, to which there was exception, and ordered a sale of the land, did not establish the validity of appellant's lien as res judicata, so that the court could not afterwards consider the question of the invalidity of the lien as against other lien creditors, afterwards setting up by petition alleged error of law in the holding of such decrees apparent from the record, whether appellees were or were not formal parties to the cause before the decrees were entered, since the decrees were not final. Motley v. H. Vicello & Bro., 132 Va. 281, 111 S.E. 295 (1922).

Attorney fees. - A fraudulent conveyance is not a fraud for which additional attorney's fees, beyond what the statute allows, may be awarded. Simons v. Wassenaar (In re Wassenaar), 268 Bankr. 477, 2001 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 17306 (W.D. Va. 2001).

The court did not err in determining the amount of attorney's fees to be awarded where the court found (1) that some legal research was excessive, (2) that some fees were simply the normal collection activities of a creditor, and (3) that some fees were not related to the fraudulent conveyance action and were, therefore, unrecoverable under the statute. Simons v. Wassenaar (In re Wassenaar), 268 Bankr. 477, 2001 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 17306 (W.D. Va. 2001).

§ 55.1-403. Creditor's action; attorney fees.

In any action brought by a creditor pursuant to § 55.1-400, 55.1-401, or 55.1-402, where a (i) gift; (ii) deed; (iii) conveyance, assignment, or transfer of or charge upon the estate of a debtor; (iv) action commenced or judgment or execution suffered or obtained; or (v) bond or other writing is declared void, the court shall award counsel for the creditor reasonable attorney fees against the debtor. Upon a finding of fraudulent conveyance pursuant to § 55.1-400, the court may assess sanctions, including such attorney fees, against all parties over which it has jurisdiction who, with the intent to defraud and having knowledge of the judgment, participated in the conveyance. Should there be a resulting judicial sale, any award of attorney fees shall be paid out of the proceeds of the sale, as other costs are paid, provided that the award of attorney fees does not affect a prior lien creditor not represented by the attorney.

(2009, c. 593, § 55-82.1; 2012, c. 810; 2019, c. 712.)

Effective date. - This section is effective October 1, 2019.

§ 55.1-404. Authority of court to set aside.

The court may set aside a fraudulent conveyance or voluntary transfer pursuant to § 55.1-400 or 55.1-401 during an action brought by a creditor to execute on a judgment, either on motion of the creditor or on its own motion, provided that all parties who have an interest in the property subject to the conveyance or transfer are given notice of the proceeding. The court, by order, may direct the clerk to issue the proper process against such parties and, upon the maturing of the case, proceed to make such orders as would have been proper if the new parties had been made parties at the commencement of the action.

(2012, c. 810, § 55-82.2; 2019, c. 712.)

Effective date. - This section is effective October 1, 2019.

§ 55.1-405. Loans and reservations of a use or property to be recorded.

When any loan of personal property is pretended to have been made to any person with whom, or with those claiming under him, possession has remained five years without demand made and pursued by due process of law on the part of the pretended lender, or when any reservation or limitation is pretended to have been made of a use or property by way of condition, reversion, remainder, or otherwise in personal property, the possession of which has so remained in another as aforesaid, the absolute property shall be taken to be with the possession and such loan, reservation, or limitation void as to creditors of, and purchasers from, the person so remaining in possession, unless such loan, reservation, or limitation is declared by will which, or a copy of which, or by deed or other writing which, is duly recorded within a period of five years in the circuit court of the county or city in which the personal property is located.

(Code 1919, § 5188; Code 1950, § 55-87; 2019, c. 712.)

Effective date. - This section is effective October 1, 2019.

Michie's Jurisprudence. - For related discussion, see 9A M.J. Fraudulent and Voluntary Conveyances, § 39; 15 M.J. Recording Acts, § 6.

CASE NOTES

  • I. [Reserved.]
  • II. Decided Under Prior Law.
I. [RESERVED.]
II. DECIDED UNDER PRIOR LAW.

Parol loan is taken to be fraudulent after five years. - Under the act to prevent frauds and perjuries, a loan of goods and chattels made by parol, to a person with whom, or those claiming under him, possession remains five years, without demand made and pursued by due process of law on the part of the lender, is taken to be fraudulent as to the creditors and purchasers of the persons so remaining in possession. Beasley v. Owen, 13 Va. (3 Hen. & M.) 449 (1809); Gay v. Moseley, 16 Va. (2 Munf.) 543 (1811); Lacy v. Wilson, 18 Va. (4 Munf.) 313 (1814); Garth's Ex'rs v. Barksdale, 19 Va. (5 Munf.) 101 (1816); Durham v. Dunkly, 27 Va. (6 Rand.) 135 (1828); Pate v. Baker, 35 Va. (8 Leigh) 80 (1837); Lightfoot v. Strother, 36 Va. (9 Leigh) 451 (1838); London v. Turner, 38 Va. (11 Leigh) 403 (1840); Taylor v. Beale, 45 Va. (4 Gratt.) 93 (1847).

But it remains valid between the parties. - A loan of chattels, though not in writing duly recorded, and therefore void as to creditors, the borrower having continued in possession five years without such demand as would bar their right, is nevertheless effectual between the parties and their representatives, however long the borrower may keep possession. Boyd v. Stainback, 19 Va. (5 Munf.) 305 (1817); Scott v. Jones, 76 Va. 233 (1882). See London v. Turner, 38 Va. (11 Leigh) 403 (1840).

As does parol trust. - Although, where personal property is given to one upon a trust by parol for another, the declaration of trust by parol may be valid as between the donee and the cestui que trust, yet as between the cestui que trust and the creditors of the donee the case is essentially different. London v. Turner, 38 Va. (11 Leigh) 403 (1840).

Choses in action are not "goods or chattels." - Sections 55-3 and 55-96 and this section all relate to gifts, loans, sales, or partition of the same kind of property, described by the same terms, namely, "goods or chattels" or "goods and chattels." They are closely connected in subject matter and in the language employed, and it can hardly be doubted that whatever was meant by the words "goods or chattels" or "goods and chattels" in any one of these sections must have been intended of the same words in each of the other sections. These words do not apply to choses in action, but only to visible and tangible property. First Nat'l Bank v. Holland, 99 Va. 495, 39 S.E. 126 (1901).

Section does not apply to property remaining in possession on hire. - This section does not apply to the case of property remaining in possession of a debtor for more than five years on hire. M'Kenzie v. Macon, 46 Va. (5 Gratt.) 379 (1849).

Nor to possession of mortgagor after mortgage duly recorded. See Rose's Adm'x v. Burgess, 37 Va. (10 Leigh) 186 (1839).

And purchaser from borrower cannot claim benefit of his own possession. - Where possession has not, at the time of a sale, remained five years with the borrower and those claiming under him, the purchaser can have no benefit from this section by reason of his own possession after the purchase. The circumstances that the possession by the borrower before the sale, and the possession by the purchaser after the sale, will together make five years cannot avail to give a title to the purchaser. Lightfoot v. Strother, 36 Va. (9 Leigh) 451 (1838).

Operation of section is avoided by resumption of possession by grant of chattel to another. - The operation of this section will be avoided by the lender's resuming possession, or granting the chattels to another by writing duly recorded, within five years. Collins v. Lofftus & Co., 37 Va. (10 Leigh) 5 (1839); Scott v. Jones, 76 Va. 233 (1882).

But not by private demand, receipt and redelivery to borrower. - A demand for chattels by the lender, who thereupon receives and immediately redelivers them to the borrower to be held on the same terms as before, the demand, receipt, and redelivery being in private, is not sufficient to bar the rights of creditors under this section. Boyd v. Stainback, 19 Va. (5 Munf.) 305 (1817).

Or resumption of possession or recordation after five years. - Five years peaceable and uninterrupted possession of chattels under a loan not evidenced by deed duly recorded, vests a title in the borrower which inures in favor of his creditors, and cannot be divested as to them by his returning the chattels to the lender after the five years have expired. Garth's Ex'rs v. Barksdale, 19 Va. (5 Munf.) 101 (1816); Taylor v. Beale, 45 Va. (4 Gratt.) 93 (1847). See London v. Turner, 38 Va. (11 Leigh) 403 (1840).

If a debtor remains in possession of chattels for five years, under a parol loan, they are liable to satisfy his creditors, though possession is resumed by the lender before executions are levied upon them. Garth's Ex'rs v. Barksdale, 19 Va. (5 Munf.) 101 (1816); Taylor v. Beale, 45 Va. (4 Gratt.) 93 (1847); Beale v. Digges, 47 Va. (6 Gratt.) 582 (1850).

Where, after a loan to a person with whom, or with those claiming under him, possession has remained five years, a deed is made and recorded by the lender, the deed cannot affect a creditor of the person in possession, and ought not to be received as evidence against such creditor. Pate v. Baker, 35 Va. (8 Leigh) 80 (1837).

Until five years after such resumption of possession. - Where possession has remained with the borrower, or with those claiming under him, for five years, and is then resumed by the lender, the possession must continue with the lender for the full period of five years from the time it was actually resumed before the title will be revested in the lender as against a creditor of the borrower. Pate v. Baker, 35 Va. (8 Leigh) 80 (1837).

But only creditors existing when lender resumes possession are protected. - If no writing declaring a loan is recorded, or no demand is made by the lender and pursued by course of law, for more than five years after possession is commenced, the loan is void as to the borrower's creditor, whose rights cannot be affected by lender's subsequent resumption of possession. But the creditors meant are those whose debts were contracted before the resumption of possession, or conveyance of the chattels, by the lender, they having given credit to loanee on the apparent ownership of the property. Scott v. Jones, 76 Va. 233 (1882).

And recordation vacates loan as to debts subsequently contracted. - A deed recorded after possession has remained with a borrower more than five years vacates the loan, not as to debts contracted by the borrower before, but as to those contracted after, its recordation; and the onus is on the creditor to show that his debt was contracted before the deed was recorded, in order to render the property liable. Scott v. Jones, 76 Va. 233 (1882).

Effect of defective recordation. - See Lacy v. Wilson, 18 Va. (4 Munf.) 313 (1814).

§ 55.1-406. Certain recorded contracts as valid as deeds.

Any such contract or bill of sale as is mentioned in § 11-1, if in writing and signed by the owner of the property, shall, from the time it is duly recorded, be, as against creditors and purchasers, as valid, so far as it affects real estate, as if the contract were a deed conveying the estate or interest embraced in the contract and, so far as it affects goods and chattels, as if possession had completely passed at the time of such recording, provided that, as to goods whose possession is retained by a merchant-seller, the provisions of subsection (2) of § 8.2-402 of the Uniform Commercial Code shall be controlling and provided further that, if any such contract or bill of sale as is mentioned in § 11-1 creates a security interest as defined in the Uniform Commercial Code, its validity and enforceability shall be governed by the provisions of that Code.

(Code 1919, § 5193; Code 1950, § 55-95; 1964, c. 314; 1966, c. 399; 2019, c. 712.)

Effective date. - This section is effective October 1, 2019.

Law review. - For note on the developing law in Virginia on installment land contracts, see 37 Wash. & Lee L. Rev. 1161 (1980). For article discussing due-on-sale clauses in home-purchasing contracts, see 16 U. Rich. L. Rev. 35 (1982).

Michie's Jurisprudence. - For related discussion, see 2A M.J. Assignments for the Benefit of Creditors, § 9; 2A M.J. Attachment and Garnishment, §§ 64, 73; 2C M.J. Bankruptcy, § 93; 3C M.J. Commercial Law, §§ 20, 95; 15 M.J. Recording Acts, §§ 2, 4.

CASE NOTES

  • I. [Reserved.]
  • II. Decided Under Prior Law.
I. [RESERVED.]
II. DECIDED UNDER PRIOR LAW.

The manifest purpose of this section and §§ 11-1 and 55-96 is to protect creditors against debtors who give a deceptive appearance of ownership by retaining possession after title has passed to a stranger to the creditor-debtor relationship. Graves Constr. Co. v. Rockingham Nat'l Bank, 220 Va. 844, 263 S.E.2d 408 (1980).

This section and §§ 11-1 and 55-96 to be read together. - This section and §§ 11-1 and 55-96 were intended to render our registry laws more nearly perfect, and might very properly have been embraced in one section. This section and § 55-96 are so connected with and dependent upon § 11-1 that they must be read with it in order to ascertain what is meant by the terms any such contract" and "every such contract in writing," as used in those sections, respectively. Norfolk & Portsmouth Traction Co. v. C.B. White & Bros., 113 Va. 102, 73 S.E. 467 (1912).

Recordation of contract not required to be recorded. - This section and §§ 11-1 and 55-96 do not authorize the recordation of any contract relating to personal property, except a contract for the sale of personalty made in consideration of marriage [and one under which possession is allowed to remain in the grantor], and recordation of a contract not required to be recorded is not notice to a subsequent purchaser of the property for value and without notice. Braxton v. Bell, 92 Va. 229, 23 S.E. 289 (1895).

Abandonment of recorded contract. - Appellant sought to enjoin the enforcement of a judgment lien against land which had been conveyed to her father by one to whom it had been conveyed by the judgment debtor by a deed which was never recorded. Prior to the conveyance to the grantor of appellant's father, the judgment debtor and his wife had executed a title bond or contract of sale under which they were to convey the property to another party, which contract was duly recorded prior to the docketing of the judgment. Appellant contended that this title bond was in legal effect a deed, and, since it was recorded prior to the docketing of the judgment, that the judgment could never have been a lien against the land. The other party to the contract of sale joined with the judgment debtor in the conveyance to the grantor of appellant's father, in which conveyance it was stated that the contract of sale had been rescinded and that the other party to the contract joined in such deed as a release deed. It was held that any claim under the title bond or contract had been abandoned and such bond or contract was a nullity, and the land was subject to the judgment lien. Cox v. Williams, 183 Va. 152, 31 S.E.2d 312 (1944).

The trustee in bankruptcy, as a lien creditor, takes the bankrupt's real estate free from most hidden interests. In re Smith, 348 F. Supp. 1290 (E.D. Va. 1972).

Resulting trust. - Where one holds the legal title to real estate which is impressed in his hands with a resulting trust, such trust may be enforced and is good against his judgment creditors. In re Smith, 348 F. Supp. 1290 (E.D. Va. 1972).

OPINIONS OF THE ATTORNEY GENERAL

Editor's note. - The opinion cited below refers to prior law.

Recordation tax based on amount of indebtedness. - When the amount secured by a deed of trust is known, the clerk of court should calculate the recordation tax based on the amount of indebtedness rather than the fair market value of the encumbered property. See opinion of Attorney General to The Honorable Yvonne G. Smith, Clerk of the Circuit Court of Henrico County, 11-073, 2011 Va. AG LEXIS 33 (5/27/11).

§ 55.1-407. Contracts, etc., void as to creditors and purchasers until recorded; priority of credit line deed of trust.

    1. Every (i) contract in writing; (ii) deed conveying any estate or term; (iii) deed of gift, or deed of trust, or mortgage conveying real estate or personal property; and (iv) bill of sale, or contract for the sale of personal property, when the possession is allowed to remain with the grantor, shall be void as to all purchasers for valuable consideration without notice not parties thereto and lien creditors, until and except from the time it is recorded in the county or city in which the property subject to such contract, deed, or bill of sale is located. The fact that any such instrument is in the form of or contains the terms of a quit-claim or release shall not prevent the grantee from being a purchaser for valuable consideration without notice, nor be of itself notice to such grantee of any unrecorded conveyance of or encumbrance upon such real estate or personal property. The mere possession of real estate shall not, of itself, be notice to purchasers for value of any interest or estate therein of the person in possession. As to personal property whose possession is retained by a merchant-seller, the provisions of subsection (2) of § 8.2-402 of the Uniform Commercial Code shall control. This section shall not apply to any security interest in personal property under the Uniform Commercial Code. Any bill of sale or contract for the sale of personal property when possession is allowed to remain with the grantor shall be deemed to be duly recorded when it is filed in the same manner as Uniform Commercial Code financing statements are filed under the criteria and in the places established by § 8.9A-501 as if the grantor were a debtor and the grantee a secured party. A recordation under the provisions of this section shall, when any real estate subject to the lien of any such contract has been annexed to or merged with an adjoining city subsequent to such docketing, be deemed to have been recorded in the proper clerk's office of such city. A. 1. Every (i) contract in writing; (ii) deed conveying any estate or term; (iii) deed of gift, or deed of trust, or mortgage conveying real estate or personal property; and (iv) bill of sale, or contract for the sale of personal property, when the possession is allowed to remain with the grantor, shall be void as to all purchasers for valuable consideration without notice not parties thereto and lien creditors, until and except from the time it is recorded in the county or city in which the property subject to such contract, deed, or bill of sale is located. The fact that any such instrument is in the form of or contains the terms of a quit-claim or release shall not prevent the grantee from being a purchaser for valuable consideration without notice, nor be of itself notice to such grantee of any unrecorded conveyance of or encumbrance upon such real estate or personal property. The mere possession of real estate shall not, of itself, be notice to purchasers for value of any interest or estate therein of the person in possession. As to personal property whose possession is retained by a merchant-seller, the provisions of subsection (2) of § 8.2-402 of the Uniform Commercial Code shall control. This section shall not apply to any security interest in personal property under the Uniform Commercial Code. Any bill of sale or contract for the sale of personal property when possession is allowed to remain with the grantor shall be deemed to be duly recorded when it is filed in the same manner as Uniform Commercial Code financing statements are filed under the criteria and in the places established by § 8.9A-501 as if the grantor were a debtor and the grantee a secured party. A recordation under the provisions of this section shall, when any real estate subject to the lien of any such contract has been annexed to or merged with an adjoining city subsequent to such docketing, be deemed to have been recorded in the proper clerk's office of such city.
    2. The clerk of each court in which any such instrument is by law required to be recorded shall keep a daily index of all such instruments admitted to record in his office, and, immediately upon recording such instrument, the clerk shall index the same either in the daily index or the appropriate general index of his office. All instruments indexed in the daily index shall be indexed by the clerk in the appropriate general index within 90 days after recording. During the period permitted for transfer from the daily index to the general index, indexing in the daily index shall be a sufficient compliance with the requirements of this section as to indexing.
      1. In any circuit court in which any such instrument required to be recorded is not recorded on the same day as delivered, the clerk shall install a time stamp machine. The time stamp machine shall affix the current date and time of each delivery of any instrument delivered to the clerk for recording that is not immediately recorded and entered into the general or daily index. 3. a. In any circuit court in which any such instrument required to be recorded is not recorded on the same day as delivered, the clerk shall install a time stamp machine. The time stamp machine shall affix the current date and time of each delivery of any instrument delivered to the clerk for recording that is not immediately recorded and entered into the general or daily index.
      2. In the event that a time stamp machine has not been installed or is not functioning, the clerk shall designate an employee to affix the current date and time of each delivery of any instrument delivered to the clerk for recording.
      3. In any circuit court in which instruments required to be recorded are not recorded on the same day as delivered, for purposes of subdivision 1, the term "from the time it is recorded" shall be presumed to be the date and time affixed upon the instrument by the time stamp machine or affixed by the clerk in accordance with subdivision b unless the clerk determines that the applicable requirements for recordation of the instrument have not been satisfied.
      4. The provisions of subdivision 3 shall not apply to certificates of satisfaction or partial satisfaction or assignments of deeds of trust delivered to the clerk's office other than by hand.
  2. A credit line deed of trust, recorded pursuant to § 55.1-318, is valid and has priority over any (i) contract in writing, deed, conveyance, or other instrument conveying any such estate or term subsequently recorded or (ii) judgment subsequently docketed as to all advances made under such credit line deed of trust from the date of recordation of such credit line deed of trust, whether or not the particular advance or extension of credit has been made or unconditionally committed at the time of delivery or recordation of such contract in writing, deed, or other instrument or the docketing of such judgment. Any judgment creditor shall have the right to give the notice contemplated by § 55.1-318 and, from the day following receipt of such notice, the judgment as docketed shall have priority over all subsequent advances made pursuant to the credit line deed of trust except those that have been unconditionally and irrevocably committed prior to such date. Mechanics' liens created under Title 43 shall continue to have the same priority as created by that title. Purchase money security interests in goods and fixtures shall have the same priority as provided in Part 3 of Title 8.9A (§ 8.9A-317 et seq.).

(Code 1919, § 5194; 1922, p. 474; 1944, p. 356; Code 1950, § 55-96; 1964, cc. 219, 309, 314; 1966, c. 400; 1974, c. 522; 1982, c. 230; 1984, c. 19; 1988, c. 51; 2003, c. 776; 2014, c. 267; 2019, c. 712.)

Cross references. - As to certificate of title as notice of security interest in motor vehicle, see § 46.2-638.

Michie's Jurisprudence. - For related discussion, see 1A M.J. Agency, § 74; 2A M.J. Assignments, § 50; 2A M.J. Assignments for the Benefit of Creditors, § 9; 2A M.J. Attachment and Garnishment, §§ 64, 73; 2C M.J. Bankruptcy, § 97; 3C M.J. Commercial Law, §§ 20, 95, 97, 101; 9A M.J. Fraudulent and Voluntary Conveyances, § 1; 11A M.J. Judgments and Decrees, §§ 52, 68, 223; 13A M.J. Mortgages and Deeds of Trust, § 38; 15 M.J. Recording Acts, §§ 2, 4, 5; 19 M.J. Vendor and Purchaser, §§ 138, 139.

Effective date. - This section is effective October 1, 2019.

CASE NOTES

  • I. [Reserved.]
  • II. Decided Under Prior Law.
    • A. General Consideration.
    • B. What Instruments are Within Recording Act.
      • 1. In General.
      • 2. Instruments Relating to Real Estate.
      • 3. Instruments Relating to Personal Property.
    • C. Requisites and Sufficiency of Recordation.
    • D. Effect of Record as Notice.
      • 1. In General.
      • 2. Persons Affected With Notice.
    • E. Effect of Failure to Record.
      • 1. As Between Parties.
      • 2. As Against Creditors.
      • 3. As Against Purchasers.
        • a. In General.
        • b. Constructive Notice.
I. [RESERVED.]
II. DECIDED UNDER PRIOR LAW.
A. GENERAL CONSIDERATION.

For the history of this section, see Jones v. Folks, 149 Va. 140, 140 S.E. 126 (1927).

The chief object of this section is to benefit creditors and subsequent purchasers, by enabling them to know whom they may credit, and from whom they may safely purchase. Pillow v. Southwest Va. Imp. Co., 92 Va. 144, 23 S.E. 32 (1956).

The main purpose of recordation statutes such as this section is to give constructive notice to purchasers and encumbrancers who acquire or seek to acquire some interest or right in property. Chavis v. Gibbs, 198 Va. 379, 94 S.E.2d 195 (1956).

The manifest purpose of this section and §§ 11-1 and 55-95 is to protect creditors against debtors who give a deceptive appearance of ownership by retaining possession after title has passed to a stranger to the creditor-debtor relationship. Graves Constr. Co. v. Rockingham Nat'l Bank, 220 Va. 844, 263 S.E.2d 408 (1980).

This section states the "first in time, first in right" doctrine. In re Shirley, 128 Bankr. 724 (Bankr. W.D. Va. 1991).

Section 8.01-458 must be read in conjunction with this section. Leake v. Finance One Mtg., Inc. (In re Snyder), 57 Bankr. 438 (Bankr. W.D. Va. 1985).

Section 43-21 modifies this section. - The effect of § 43-21 is to modify the registry law as contained in this section so far as to give priority to a mechanics' lien on the lands of the grantee, who has failed to record his deed, over judgments subsequently obtained against his grantor. Pace v. Moorman, 99 Va. 246, 37 S.E. 911 (1901).

Time of recording held time of transfer for purposes of Bankruptcy Act. - For the purpose of determining whether or not a transaction constitutes a voidable preference under the federal Bankruptcy Act, title to personal property, the subject of a bill of sale under which possession is to remain in the grantor, does not pass until the bill of sale is recorded. In re Montague, 143 F. 428 (E.D. Va. 1905).

The trustee in bankruptcy, as a lien creditor, takes the bankrupt's real estate free from most hidden interests. In re Smith, 348 F. Supp. 1290 (E.D. Va. 1972).

Resulting trust. - Where one holds the legal title to real estate which is impressed in his hands with a resulting trust, such trust may be enforced and is good against his judgment creditors. In re Smith, 348 F. Supp. 1290 (E.D. Va. 1972).

Pleading. - In a suit by the grantee in an unrecorded deed to set aside a later conveyance of the same property, if the defendants were entitled to the protection of this section, that was a matter of defense to the benefit of which they could entitle themselves only by affirmative pleading setting up such defense and by proof sustaining such pleading. Blizzard v. Salyer, 125 Va. 604, 100 S.E. 454 (1919).

B. WHAT INSTRUMENTS ARE WITHIN RECORDING ACT.
1. IN GENERAL.

Applicability. - Transfer of property to a debtor's spouse pursuant to the terms of a marital agreement was deemed not to have occurred until the marital agreement was perfected by recording, pursuant to § 11-1 and § 55-96. Prunty v. Terry (In re Paschall), 408 Bankr. 79, 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 45623 (E.D. Va. 2009), aff'd, 388 Fed. Appx. 299, 2010 U.S. App. LEXIS 14613 (4th Cir. Va. 2010).

United States is exempt from state registry laws. - The United States, as an incident of its sovereignty, has capacity to contract coextensive with the duties and powers of government, and this power carries with it complete exemption from all obligation to comply with state registry laws. It is not necessary for it to comply with the registry laws of the State in order to preserve a lien created by contract with it. The lien, without recordation, simply takes its place, and is superior to the claims of all other creditors who have no prior lien. United States v. Wm. R. Trigg Co., 115 Va. 272, 78 S.E. 542 (1913).

This section and §§ 11-1 and 55-95 to be read together. - This section and §§ 11-1 and 55-95 were intended to render our registry laws more nearly perfect, and might very properly have been embraced in one section. This section and § 55-95 are so connected with and dependent upon § 11-1 that they must be read with it in order to ascertain what is meant by the terms "any such contract" and "every such contract in writing," as used in these sections, respectively. Norfolk & Portsmouth Traction Co. v. C.B. White & Bros., 113 Va. 102, 73 S.E. 467 (1912).

2. INSTRUMENTS RELATING TO REAL ESTATE.

Conveyances and contracts to convey are placed on same footing. - This section effectually abrogates the rule laid down in Withers v. Carter, 45 Va. (4 Gratt.) 405 (1848), so far as executory contracts in writing for the sale of land are concerned, and places them on the same footing as conveyances of the legal title. Edison v. Huff, 70 Va. (29 Gratt.) 338 (1877); Hart v. Haynes, 1 Va. Dec. 201 (1877).

Deeds of conveyance. - A deed conveying real estate is void as against creditors and purchasers until and except from the time it is duly admitted to record. Tapp v. Beverley, 28 Va. (1 Leigh) 80 (1829); M'Clure v. Thistle's Ex'r, 43 Va. (2 Gratt.) 182 (1845); Russell v. Randolph, 67 Va. (26 Gratt.) 705 (1875); Solenburger v. Duval, 1 Va. Dec. 100 (1876); Grasswitt's Assignee v. Connally, 68 Va. (27 Gratt.) 19 (1876); Edison v. Huff, 70 Va. (29 Gratt.) 338 (1877); Young v. Devries, 72 Va. (31 Gratt.) 304 (1879); Slater v. Moore, 86 Va. 26, 9 S.E. 419 (1889); Corey v. Moore, 86 Va. 721, 11 S.E. 114 (1890); Robinson v. Commercial & Farmers' Bank, 1 Va. Dec. 769, 17 S.E. 739 (1893); Flanary v. Kane, 102 Va. 547, 46 S.E. 312, rehearing denied, 102 Va. 565, 46 S.E. 681 (1904).

Section applies to lien creditors irrespective of actual notice. - Although this section applies only to those purchasers without notice, the statute nevertheless applies to lien creditors irrespective of actual notice. Because the contract of sale entered into upon the deed of trust sale in the instant case was not "duly admitted to record" at the time the finance company docketed its judgment, said contract was, pursuant to this section, void as against finance company. Leake v. Finance One Mtg., Inc. (In re Snyder), 57 Bankr. 438 (Bankr. W.D. Va. 1985).

An undelivered deed filed as an escrow in the proceedings of a court of equity, administering a trust fund belonging to a married woman and her infant children, is not within the terms or intendment of this section. Trout's Adm'r v. Warwick, 77 Va. 731 (1883).

Contracts affecting title. - Under this section, contracts affecting title to real estate should be properly recorded to protect interested parties from losing priority to subsequent purchasers. In other words, the Code of Virginia requires owners or holders of an interest in property to disclose this interest. In re Wilkinson, 175 Bankr. 627 (Bankr. E.D. Va. 1994).

In a suit between individuals to set aside as a fraudulent conveyance a deed of trust regarding certain real property, where an intervenor bank did not have a claim to this property by an equitable lien from its possession and a certain contract regarding the property, even if the bank had an equitable interest in the property, its interest was junior to that of the parties because it failed to comply with state recording statutes, and under § 11-1, a contract for the conveyance of real estate had to be in writing, and under § 55-96, a contract conveying property was void as to all bona fide purchasers or creditors without notice of it until it was recorded. Hung-Lin Wu v. Tseng, 459 F. Supp. 2d 468, 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 75608 (E.D. Va. 2006).

Contract for purchase of right-of-way. - A parol contract for the purchase of a right-of-way for a street railway over a strip of land is a contract "made in respect to real estate" within the meaning of this section. Norfolk & Portsmouth Traction Co. v. C.B. White & Bros., 113 Va. 102, 73 S.E. 467 (1912). See Moore v. Postal Tel. Cable Co., 3 Va. L. Reg. (n.s.) 111 (1917).

Contract for lease for term of more than five years. - This section and § 11-1 read together, provide that every contract in writing for the conveyance or sale of real estate, or of a term therein of more than five years, shall be void both at law and in equity, as to purchasers for valuable consideration without notice, until and except from the time that it is duly admitted to record. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co. v. Cofer, 129 Va. 640, 106 S.E. 695 (1921).

A lease not recorded is void as to a purchaser. Knight v. Triplet, Jeff. 71 (1740).

Lease for two years with privilege of renewals must be recorded. - By an indenture containing a demise of property for two years and one month, with the privilege to the lessee at his option of four successive renewals, each for a period of one year, the lessor has definitely parted with the control of his property for the full period to which the instrument related. Hence the paper constitutes a single contract giving the lessee a demise and four options, and it is not four several contracts of option. And a contract which provides an actual demise of real estate for two years and one month, and the means by which the lessee's enjoyment of the premises can be extended for four years more, is a contract for a term of more than five years in real estate and, as against a subsequent purchaser for value and without notice, must be recorded. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co. v. Cofer, 129 Va. 640, 106 S.E. 695 (1921).

Lease is not to be partitioned into a five-year portion and a greater than five-year portion. - The court rejected defendant's argument, based on Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co. v. Cofer , 129 Va. 640, 106 S.E. 695 (1921), that if the lease is indeed void under the Virginia recording statute, it is void only as to the portion of the lease for a term greater than five years. Because the lease in this case has run for slightly more than three years, the defendant could not then argue that the lease would be valid for a period of five years and only after that date would the lease be considered void. Watts Contrs., Inc. v. Watts (In re Watts Contrs., Inc.), 360 Bankr. 489, 2007 Bankr. LEXIS 109 (Bankr. E.D. Va. 2007).

Long-term leases. - Subdivision A 1 of § 55-96 can not be read to apply the recording requirement to deeds conveying estates only when possession of the deed is allowed to remain with the grantor: (1) the recording statute is consistently understood to say that deeds conveying leases for terms of more than five years are to be recorded; (2) the phrase, "when the possession is allowed to remain with the grantor," clearly modifies only contracts for the sale of goods and chattels; (3) a lease for a term of more than five years must be recorded or it is void as to a bona fide purchaser; and (4) the Virginia recording statute does not allow unrecorded, long-term leases to be treated in a bifurcated fashion, voiding only that portion of the lease that extends beyond a five year term. Watts Contrs., Inc. v. Watts (In re Watts Contrs., Inc.), 360 Bankr. 489, 2007 Bankr. LEXIS 109 (Bankr. E.D. Va. 2007).

3. INSTRUMENTS RELATING TO PERSONAL PROPERTY.

This section and § 55-3 should be construed together. - Section 55-3 and this section are so closely related as to the subject matter of gifts that they may be said to be in pari materia, and should be construed together. Both relate to goods and chattels; § 55-3 wholly, and this section in part. First Nat'l Bank v. Holland, 99 Va. 495, 39 S.E. 126 (1901).

"Goods and chattels" has same meaning in §§ 55-3, 55-87, 55-95 and this section. - Sections 55-3, 55-87, 55-95 and this section all relate to gifts, loans, sales or partition of the same kind of property, described by the same terms - namely, "goods or chattels" or "goods and chattels." They are closely connected in subject matter and in the language employed, and it can hardly be doubted that whatever was meant by the words "goods or chattels" or "goods and chattels" in any one of these sections must have been intended of the same words in each of the other sections. First Nat'l Bank v. Holland, 99 Va. 495, 39 S.E. 126 (1901).

Choses in action are not "goods and chattels." - The words "goods and chattels" as used in this section do not include a mere chose in action, as a debt, or claim on another for money due; and the assignment of a debt or claim for value, though not recorded, will be good against a subsequent attachment. Kirkland, Chase & Co. v. Brune, 72 Va. (31 Gratt.) 126 (1878). See First Nat'l Bank v. Holland, 99 Va. 495, 39 S.E. 126 (1901).

Term is restricted to visible, tangible and movable personalty. - The words "goods and chattels" refer to and include only personal property which is visible, tangible, or movable. Kirkland, Chase & Co. v. Brune, 72 Va. (31 Gratt.) 126 (1878).

And assignments of choses in action need not be recorded. Gregg v. Sloan, 76 Va. 497 (1882); Gordon v. Rixey, 76 Va. 694 (1882); Daily's Ex'r v. Warren, 80 Va. 512 (1885).

Assignments for the purpose of transferring certain bonds, with no purpose of creating or evidencing a contract with the obligor, who was not a party to the assignments, did not constitute a contract in writing between the obligor and the assignee within the meaning of this section. McClanahan's Adm'r v. Norfolk & W. Ry., 122 Va. 705, 96 S.E. 453 (1918).

Debts secured by mortgage on land. - Debtors in North Carolina granted all their property, including choses in action due from their debtors in Virginia and secured on land here. After recordation of the deed in North Carolina, but before its recordation in Virginia a creditor of the grantors, living in Virginia, attached the choses and the land securing them. In a contest for priority, it was held that the deed, though unrecorded in Virginia, being prior to the attachment, prevailed over it, for this section does not require the recordation of an assignment of a chose in action and its incidental security. Gregg v. Sloan, 76 Va. 497 (1882).

A conditional sale does not come within the scope of this section. McComb v. Donald's Adm'r, 82 Va. 903, 5 S.E. 558 (1886).

A bank which discounts a draft with a bill of lading attached, if not the absolute owner of the goods, stands in the position of a mortgagee in possession and is not required, in order to protect its lien, to have the papers recorded under this section. Seward & Co. v. Miller, 106 Va. 309, 55 S.E. 681 (1906).

Possession left with grantor. - A bill of sale, not admitted to record, of personal property which has been permitted to remain in the possession of the seller, is void as to creditors of the seller, under the provisions of this section, and is not admissible in evidence in a proceeding by the purchaser to try the title to the property. It is not necessary, in order to render such a bill of sale void under this section, that it should appear by the provisions of the writing itself that the possession of the property was to remain with the seller. Fields-Watkins Co. v. Hensley, 117 Va. 661, 86 S.E. 113 (1915).

Delivery to grantee validates sale as to subsequent creditors and purchasers. - Where no real fraud is intended, a subsequent delivery would render a sale valid and effectual against all creditors whose debts were contracted, and all purchasers whose bargains were made, after such subsequent delivery. Deitz v. High, 131 Va. 7, 109 S.E. 215 (1921).

A bill of sale was executed in West Virginia and the property remained in possession of the seller in that state after the execution of the bill of sale. Before the property was removed to Virginia and before an attaching creditor had acquired any right whatever to subject the property to the payment of his debt, it was turned over to the purchaser, and the property was in the possession of the purchaser when brought into Virginia. It was held that this section had no application to the transaction. Deitz v. Whyte, 131 Va. 19, 109 S.E. 212 (1921).

Delivery of possession to trustee. - A deed is made conveying personal property to trustees for the purpose of paying debts specified therein, and the trustees took possession of the property and proceeded to sell it for the purposes of the trust. Though the deed was not duly recorded, yet, the property having been delivered to the trustees, this was a valid transfer thereof, and protected the property against the demands of creditors who had not acquired liens upon it before the transfer was consummated. Clark v. Ward, 53 Va. (12 Gratt.) 440 (1855).

Whether or not property allowed to remain with grantor is question for jury. - Where the validity of a sale of personal property was attacked because the sale was not recorded as provided for by this section, whether or not the property was allowed to remain with the vendor after the sale was a question of fact. Deitz v. High, 131 Va. 7, 109 S.E. 215 (1921).

C. REQUISITES AND SUFFICIENCY OF RECORDATION.

The mere delivery of the deed to the clerk for recordation meets all the requirements of this section. Jones v. Folks, 149 Va. 140, 140 S.E. 126 (1927). See also Beverly v. Ellis, 22 Va. (1 Rand.) 102 (1822).

A valid acknowledgment or proof of execution is a prerequisite to the registration of an instrument, and the recording of an unacknowledged or defectively acknowledged instrument has no effect whatever. Turner v. Stip, 1 Va. (1 Wash.) 319 (1794); Moore's Ex'r v. Auditor of Pub. Accounts, 13 Va. (3 Hen. & M.) 232 (1808); Carper v. M'Dowell, 46 Va. (5 Gratt.) 212 (1848); Davis v. Beazley, 75 Va. 491 (1881); Raines v. Walker, 77 Va. 92 (1883); Nicholson v. Gloucester Charity School, 93 Va. 101, 24 S.E. 899 (1896); Iron Belt Bldg. & Loan Ass'n v. Groves, 96 Va. 138, 31 S.E. 23 (1898).

Acknowledgment defect. - Bankruptcy court did not err in holding that appellant bankruptcy trustee could not invoke strong-arm avoidance powers granted to him under 11 U.S.C.S. § 544(a)(1) because, under Virginia law, despite an acknowledgment defect, the deed of trust was valid between the parties, and thus title was validly conveyed following the foreclosure sale; therefore, debtors were divested of any property interest upon which appellant bankruptcy trustee, as a hypothetical lien creditor, could have attached a lien at the time debtors' bankruptcy proceedings commenced, thus defeating the trustee's strong-arm avoidance powers. Tyler v. Ownit Mortg. Loan Trust, 460 Bankr. 458, 2011 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 124789 (E.D. Va. Oct. 28, 2011).

Deed need not be indexed to constitute notice. - This section no longer requires that a deed shall be indexed, as well as admitted to record, in order to constitute constructive notice; and this notwithstanding that the second paragraph provides in detail for an index. Jones v. Folks, 149 Va. 140, 140 S.E. 126 (1927). See Virginia Bldg. & Loan Co. v. Glenn, 99 Va. 460, 39 S.E. 136 (1901).

Once an instrument is delivered to the clerk for recording, the party delivering the instrument is not responsible for seeing that the instrument is properly indexed. Thus, whether or not a deed of trust was properly indexed, the mere fact that it was presented to the clerk for recordation would result in it being constructive notice to a subsequent mortgagee. United States v. Lomas Mtg., USA, Inc., 742 F. Supp. 936 (W.D. Va. 1990).

Place of recording contracts relating to real estate. - A deed or deed of trust conveying real estate must be recorded in the clerk's office of the county or corporation court within the jurisdiction of which the real estate is situated. Pollard's Heirs v. Lively, 43 Va. (2 Gratt.) 216 (1845); Horsley v. Garth, 43 Va. (2 Gratt.) 471 (1846); Hassler's Lessee v. King, 50 Va. (9 Gratt.) 115 (1852); Hannon v. Hannah, 50 Va. (9 Gratt.) 146 (1852); Blackford v. Hurst, 67 Va. (26 Gratt.) 203 (1875).

Chattel mortgages. - As to recording of chattel mortgages under this section, see Lane v. Mason, 32 Va. (5 Leigh) 520 (1834); Cocke v. Haxall's Ex'r, 41 Va. (2 Rob.) 470 (1843); Smith v. Smith, 60 Va. (19 Gratt.) 545 (1869); Lucado v. Tutwiler's Adm'x, 69 Va. (28 Gratt.) 39 (1877). As to filing under Uniform Commercial Code, see §§ 8.9-302, 8.9-401 et seq.

Instrument may subsequently be recorded in another locality. - There is no rule of law, statutory or otherwise, which prevents the valid subsequent recordation in other counties or cities of a deed once recorded in a given county or city. The circumstances that the other county or city is subsequently formed out of a portion of the county in which the deed was first recorded, and that it is not necessary to record the deed a second time in such other county or city, are immaterial. The original deed may be recorded in any county or city wherein the property embraced in the deed or any part thereof is located, and it will give the constructive notice provided for by this section. Abrahams v. Ball, 122 Va. 197, 94 S.E. 799 (1918).

D. EFFECT OF RECORD AS NOTICE.
1. IN GENERAL.

Object of section is to provide notice. - The very object of the legislature in enacting this section was to give the purchaser or other person dealing with the property notice of any encumbrance thereon. McCormack v. James, 36 F. 14 (W.D. Va. 1886).

Of all facts which could be discovered by searching record. - The recordation of an instrument entitled to be recorded furnishes constructive notice to subsequent purchasers and creditors of all facts which could be discovered by searching the record. Davison v. Waite, 16 Va. (2 Munf.) 527 (1811); Colquhoun v. Atkinsons, 20 Va. (6 Munf.) 550 (1820); Bell v. Hammond, 29 Va. (2 Leigh) 416 (1830); M'Clanachan v. Siter, Price & Co., 43 Va. (2 Gratt.) 280 (1845); Mundy v. Vawter, 44 Va. (3 Gratt.) 518 (1847); Clayton v. Henley, 73 Va. (32 Gratt.) 65 (1879); Coles v. Withers, 74 Va. (33 Gratt.) 186 (1880); Miller v. Holland, 84 Va. 652, 5 S.E. 701 (1888); Chapman v. Chapman, 91 Va. 397, 21 S.E. 813 (1895). See also McCauley v. Grim, 115 Va. 610, 79 S.E. 1041 (1913).

What instrument recorded must show. - In order that the registry of a conveyance may operate as constructive notice to subsequent purchasers and encumbrancers, the instrument must afford the means of not only ascertaining with accuracy what property is conveyed or affected by the instrument registered, and where it is, but its language must be such that, if a subsequent purchaser or encumbrancer should examine the instrument itself, he would obtain there actual notice of all the rights which were intended to be created or conferred by it. National Cash Register Co. v. Burrow, 110 Va. 785, 67 S.E. 370 (1910).

Where a deed on its face conveyed a lot on the west side of a certain other lot, its recordation would not be constructive notice of the conveyance of the lot on the east side of the named lot. Blair v. Rorer's Adm'r, 135 Va. 1, 116 S.E. 767, cert. denied, 262 U.S. 734, 43 S. Ct. 704, 67 L. Ed. 1206 (1923).

Recording gives no notice of instrument not required to be recorded. - Assignments of choses in action, in Virginia, are not required to be recorded, and such recordation would not affect third persons with constructive notice. Gordon v. Rixey, 76 Va. 694 (1882).

Equitable liens. - Where liens are equitable rather than statutory, they come into existence at the moment of recordation. Such recordation among the land records is sufficient notice to fulfill the requirement of notice. Guinee v. Prager (In re James R. Corbitt Co.), 20 Bankr. 460 (Bankr. E.D. Va. 1982).

Marginal correction to deed already recorded. - In the instant case, a suit by a judgment creditor to subject the lands of his debtor to his judgments, complainant insisted that a marginal correction to a deed already recorded, made and signed by his debtor and acknowledged by him before the clerk and duly recorded before complainant's judgments were recovered, did not carry constructive notice to him of the facts contained in that memorandum, on the ground that there was no law for recording such memorandum. It was held that the clerk was authorized to record such marginal correction, and the recordation carried with it the desired information as fully as if it had been formally set out in the deed, and therefore there was no merit in complainant's contention. Blair v. Rorer's Adm'r, 135 Va. 1, 116 S.E. 767, cert. denied, 262 U.S. 734, 43 S. Ct. 704, 67 L. Ed. 1206 (1923).

Statement in amended deed to land parcels which were subject to annual charges by homeowners' association which clearly indicated that such assessment would become an equitable lien when due was sufficient to convey notice that the property might be encumbered, and was more than a mere suspicion of notice. Guinee v. Prager (In re James R. Corbitt Co.), 20 Bankr. 460 (Bankr. E.D. Va. 1982).

2. PERSONS AFFECTED WITH NOTICE.

Only persons under obligation to search record are charged with notice. - The record imparts constructive notice to such persons only as would have been entitled to protection against the conveyance in case it had not been recorded, or, in other words, to such persons as are under a legal obligation to search for it. Lynchburg Perpetual Bldg. & Loan Co. v. Fellers, 96 Va. 337, 31 S.E. 505 (1898).

A record gives constructive notice only to persons in the same line of title, or, in other words, only to persons who must trace their title through the same grantor. Claiborne v. Holland, 88 Va. 1046, 14 S.E. 915 (1892); Hulvey v. Hulvey, 92 Va. 182, 23 S.E. 233 (1895); Jones v. Byrne's Ex'x, 94 Va. 751, 27 S.E. 591 (1897).

Those who acquired rights before recording are unaffected. - Only persons who acquire their rights subsequent to the recording of a prior instrument can be said to be charged with notice of it. Lynchburg Perpetual Bldg. & Loan Co. v. Fellers, 96 Va. 337, 31 S.E. 505 (1898); Bridgewater Roller Mills Co. v. Strough, 98 Va. 721, 37 S.E. 290 (1900); McClanahan's Adm'r v. Norfolk & W. Ry., 122 Va. 705, 96 S.E. 453 (1918). See also Rootes v. Holliday, 18 Va. (4 Munf.) 323 (1814); Bird v. Wilkinson, 31 Va. (4 Leigh) 266 (1833); Creigh's Heirs v. Henson, 51 Va. (10 Gratt.) 231 (1853); Clarke v. McClure, 51 Va. (10 Gratt.) 305 (1853); Lucado v. Tutwiler's Adm'x, 69 Va. (28 Gratt.) 39 (1877); Mercantile Coop. Bank v. Brown, 96 Va. 614, 32 S.E. 64 (1899).

After a purchaser of land has put his deed on record, he is not required to watch the records to ascertain whether thereafter other deeds by his grantor or judgments against him are docketed or recorded, and the same is true of deeds of trust conveying the land. The registry of a deed by a subsequent purchaser is no notice to parties who have acquired their rights before the time when the deed is registered. McClanahan's Adm'r v. Norfolk & W. Ry., 122 Va. 705, 96 S.E. 453 (1918).

Subsequent purchasers. - Deeds recorded pursuant to this section constitute constructive notice to subsequent purchasers, and the titles they take are subject to whatever adverse conveyances or encumbrances they should have discovered in a proper search of the records. Faison v. Union Camp Corp., 224 Va. 54, 294 S.E.2d 821 (1982).

The chapter 11 trustee's strong-arm powers under 11 U.S.C.S. § 544(a) trumped the claim of a constructive trust asserted under 11 U.S.C.S. § 541(d) by a creditor whose deed of trust had been fraudulently released because, under § 55-96, a constructive trust would not be enforceable against a bona fide purchaser. HSBC Bank USA, N.A. v. Gold (In re Taneja), 427 Bankr. 109, 2010 Bankr. LEXIS 863 (Bankr. E.D. Va. 2010).

Constructive notice. - Trial court properly affirmed an easement claimed by plaintiff county in a road and landing, as defendant property owners were not innocent purchasers without constructive notice of the county's interest in the landing and road, since instruments in the owners' chain of title referring to a "public" road and landing gave them constructive notice of the county's interest in them. Shaheen v. County of Mathews, 265 Va. 462, 579 S.E.2d 162, 2003 Va. LEXIS 41 (2003).

E. EFFECT OF FAILURE TO RECORD.
1. AS BETWEEN PARTIES.

Unrecorded instrument is good between parties. - Recording, when required at all, is only requisite in order to perfect the instrument as against creditors and purchasers. As between the parties, a deed, mortgage or other instrument is valid without recordation. Turner v. Stip, 1 Va. (1 Wash.) 319 (1794); Currie v. Donald, 2 Va. (2 Wash.) 58 (1795); Guerrant v. Anderson, 25 Va. (4 Rand.) 208 (1826); Wade's Heirs v. Greenwood, 41 Va. (2 Rob.) 474 (1843); Withers v. Carter, 45 Va. (4 Gratt.) 407 (1848); McCandlish v. Keen, 54 Va. (13 Gratt.) 615 (1857); Raines v. Walker, 77 Va. 92 (1883); Welfley v. Shenandoah Iron, Lumber, Mining & Mfg. Co., 83 Va. 768, 3 S.E. 376 (1887); Barton v. Brent, 87 Va. 385, 13 S.E. 29 (1891); Thomas v. Stuart's Ex'r, 91 Va. 694, 22 S.E. 611 (1895); Building, Light & Water Co. v. Fray, 96 Va. 559, 32 S.E. 58 (1899); Hunton v. Wood, 101 Va. 54, 43 S.E. 186 (1903); Glens Falls Ins. Co. v. Sherritt, 95 F.2d 823 (4th Cir. 1938).

Recordation is only necessary as to bona fide purchasers and lien creditors without notice under Commonwealth of Virginia recording statutes; thus, as between two parties, title transfers upon delivery of the deed. Chippenham Hosp. v. Munden, 8 Bankr. 142 (Bankr. E.D. Va. 1981).

An unrecorded partition deed is good as between the parties. In the absence of fraud, it is a mutual covenant in which the parties thereto are alone interested, and its validity does not depend upon recordation under this section, because the rights of creditors are not thereby injuriously affected. Miller v. Kemp, 157 Va. 178, 160 S.E. 203 (1931).

2. AS AGAINST CREDITORS.

Deed is void as to creditors whose rights attached before recording. - A judgment creditor, whose judgment has been duly docketed, and who has brought suit to enforce the lien on the judgment debtor's land, is entitled to priority over a grantee of the judgment debtor claiming under a deed not recorded until after the commencement of the suit, after the expiration of 20 months from its execution and acknowledgment, since such a deed is void, under this section, as to creditors whose rights have attached before it was recorded. Robinson v. Commercial & Farmers' Bank, 1 Va. Dec. 769, 17 S.E. 739 (1893).

Whether or not they have actual notice. - A deed is void as against creditors "until and except from the time it is duly admitted to record." Slater v. Moore, 86 Va. 26, 9 S.E. 419 (1889).

Under this statute, a deed or instrument required to be recorded is void as to judgment creditors of the grantor, even though they have notice thereof. Cavalier Serv. Corp. v. Wise, 645 F. Supp. 31 (E.D. Va. 1986).

Circuit court properly ruled that an ex-wife's deed of trust had priority over a bank's deed of trust because, while the bank's deed of trust was recorded before the ex-wife's deed of trust, the after-acquired-title statute did not purport to affect the deeds of third parties or influence the relative priority of their interests, the bank's deed of trust was void against the ex-wife as a judgment lien creditor, and the bank's deed of trust was not properly recorded in the ex-wife's chain of title. Deutsche Bank Nat'l Trust Co. v. Arrington, 290 Va. 109, 772 S.E.2d 571, 2015 Va. LEXIS 83 (2015).

This is so notwithstanding that they have actual notice of it. Guerrant v. Anderson, 25 Va. (4 Rand.) 208 (1826); Dobyns' Adm'x v. Waring, 82 Va. 159 (1886); Heermans v. Montague, 2 Va. Dec. 6, 20 S.E. 899 (1890); Price v. Wall's Ex'r, 97 Va. 334, 33 S.E. 599 (1899). See also Bankers Loan & Inv. Co. v. Blair, 99 Va. 606, 39 S.E. 231 (1901).

A deed to an innocent purchaser is and remains void as to creditors of the grantor until admitted to record, whether such creditors do or do not know of the deed. Fooshee v. Snavely, 58 F.2d 772 (W.D. Va. 1931), aff'd, 58 F.2d 774 (4th Cir.), cert. denied, 287 U.S. 635, 53 S. Ct. 85, 77 L. Ed. 550 (1932).

Since the enactment of this section, it has never been held that an unrecorded deed of trust would be protected against judgment creditors with or without notice. Neff's Adm'r v. Newman, 150 Va. 203, 142 S.E. 389 (1928).

And notwithstanding all subsequent conveyances and proceedings in relation to the property. - See March, Price & Co. v. Chambers, 71 Va. (30 Gratt.) 299 (1878).

But only lien creditors are protected. - This section, in relation to the creditors and purchasers who shall be protected against unrecorded deeds, does not include creditors claiming under a devise for the payment of debts, or under the statute subjecting real estate to their payment. The creditor who may avoid such a deed must have some lien, by judgment or otherwise, which entitles him to charge the subject conveyed specially. McCandlish v. Keen, 54 Va. (13 Gratt.) 615 (1857).

Prior notice does not affect priority of a creditor who first records his judgment. Cavalier Serv. Corp. v. Wise, 645 F. Supp. 31 (E.D. Va. 1986).

A trustee in bankruptcy occupies the position of a lien creditor. B-W Acceptance Corp. v. Benjamin T. Crump Co., 199 Va. 312, 99 S.E.2d 606 (1957).

Chapter 7 trustee was not precluded from recovering an interest in two parcels of real property a Chapter 7 debtor conveyed to his wife as part of a divorce settlement, as a preferential transfer to an insider under 11 U.S.C.S. § 547, even though the debtor entered into the marital agreement more than a year before he declared bankruptcy. Neither the debtor nor his wife recorded the marital agreement, so the trustee did not have notice of the agreement under § 55-96. Terry v. Paschall (In re Paschall), 403 Bankr. 366, 2009 Bankr. LEXIS 938 (Bankr. E.D. Va. 2009), aff'd, 408 Bankr. 79, 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 45623 (E.D. Va. 2009).

Judgment creditors. - A deed or instrument required to be recorded is void as to judgment creditors of the grantor. M'Clure v. Thistle's Ex'r, 43 Va. (2 Gratt.) 182 (1845); McCance v. Taylor, 51 Va. (10 Gratt.) 580 (1854); Russell v. Randolph, 67 Va. (26 Gratt.) 705 (1875); Edison v. Huff, 70 Va. (29 Gratt.) 338 (1877); Robinson v. Commercial & Farmers' Bank, 1 Va. Dec. 769, 17 S.E. 739 (1893); Flanary v. Kane, 102 Va. 547, 46 S.E. 312 (1904); Blair v. Rorer's Adm'r, 135 Va. 1, 116 S.E. 767, cert. denied, 262 U.S. 734, 43 S. Ct. 704, 67 L. Ed. 1206 (1923).

Nor are such creditors affected by knowledge of the conveyance and the fact that the alienee is making improvements. Flanary v. Kane, 102 Va. 547, 46 S.E. 312 (1904).

Subsequent recorded deed to same property is valid. - If a grantee of land who has failed to record his deed induces the grantor to make a new deed to the grantee's wife, who records the same, and, together with her husband, executes a deed of trust on the property for a loan with which to pay the purchase price, the deed and deed of trust, when recorded, operate to invest the trustee with the title to the property, as against the creditors of the grantor, and they cannot subject it to judgments obtained against the grantor subsequent to the recordation. As against creditors of the grantor, the unrecorded deed is a mere nullity, and must be treated as if it had never been executed. The creditors cannot treat the deed as a nullity for some purposes, and as valid for others, nor are they affected by the fact that it may be valid between the parties and as to subsequent purchasers with notice. Bankers Loan & Inv. Co. v. Blair, 99 Va. 606, 39 S.E. 231 (1901).

Creditor's rights are not affected by possession and payment of consideration. - Where an absolute purchaser has paid a part of the purchase price and entered into possession of the land, a court of equity will limit a judgment creditor to the beneficial interest of the debtor in the property (which is the balance due) on the equitable theory that the debtor holds the property in trust to that extent for the benefit of the purchaser. But this equitable ground of priority and relief is not admitted against the positive provisions of a statute, such as this section, declaring that the enumerated writings shall be void as to creditors if not recorded, whether or not the creditor had notice of the unrecorded writings when the debt was contracted. Neff's Adm'r v. Newman, 150 Va. 203, 142 S.E. 389 (1928).

Or by fact that alienee is making improvements. - As against the creditors of a judgment debtor an unrecorded deed of the latter is a mere nullity; nor are such creditors affected by knowledge of the conveyance and the fact that the alienee is making improvements. Flanary v. Kane, 102 Va. 547, 46 S.E. 312 (1904). See also Price v. Wall, 97 Va. 334, 33 S.E. 599 (1899).

Or by character of consideration for unrecorded deed. - If upon an exchange of lands the parties execute mutual conveyances, but the grantee of one tract fails to record his deed, a judgment against his grantor binds the land so given in exchange as well as that received in exchange. The rights of the parties are not affected by the character of the consideration for the unrecorded deed. Price v. Wall, 97 Va. 334, 33 S.E. 599 (1899).

Or by agreement to which creditor is not a party. - The fact that two lien holders, whose liens were recorded, expressly agreed to subordinate their debts to an unrecorded deed of trust upon the same property is in no sense binding upon a judgment creditor as to whom the unrecorded deed of trust under this section was void. Neff's Adm'r v. Newman, 150 Va. 203, 142 S.E. 389 (1928).

A postnuptial settlement, made in consideration of the wife's releasing her dower in certain lands of her husband, is, if unrecorded, void as to creditors of the husband, and as against the creditors the wife will be held to the value of the interest relinquished. Strayer v. Long, 86 Va. 557, 10 S.E. 574 (1890).

Bankruptcy sale. - Pursuant to Virginia common law and subdivision A 1 of § 55-96, a deed conveying real property from a corporate entity to a debtor, which was delivered to the debtor before the creditor's completed foreclosure sale, was not valid as to the creditor and the purchaser of property because it was not recorded until after the sale's completion; accordingly, the sale was complete before the transfer of the entity's interest to the debtor, the property was not part of the bankruptcy estate, and the sale did not violate the automatic stay of 11 U.S.C.S. § 362(a). Lee v. Midfirst Bank (In re Lee),, 2005 Bankr. LEXIS 1203 (Bankr. E.D. Va. Feb. 11, 2005).

Trustee was entitled to avoid interest. - Chapter 7 trustee was entitled to avoid the interest of creditor lender, under 11 U.S.C.S. §§ 544(a), 547, and § 55-96, where the lender's deed of trust failed to name the proper grantor and was defective, and the recording of a lis pendens constituted an avoidable transfer. Terry v. Fidelity Nat'l Title Ins. Co. (In re Ware),, 2013 Bankr. LEXIS 1051 (Bankr. E.D. Va. Mar. 20, 2013).

3. AS AGAINST PURCHASERS.
a. IN GENERAL.

Purchasers without notice. - Failure to record an instrument required to be recorded renders it void as to subsequent purchasers for value and without notice. Guerrant v. Anderson, 25 Va. (4 Rand.) 208 (1826); Wickham v. Lewis Martin & Co., 54 Va. (13 Gratt.) 427 (1856); Davis v. Miller, 55 Va. (14 Gratt.) 1 (1857); Evans v. Greenhow, 56 Va. (15 Gratt.) 153 (1859); Exchange Bank v. Knox, 60 Va. (19 Gratt.) 739 (1870); Cammack v. Soran, 71 Va. (30 Gratt.) 292 (1878); Harman v. Oberdorfer, 74 Va. (33 Gratt.) 497 (1880); Williams v. Lord, 75 Va. 300 (1881); Witz, Biedler & Co. v. Osburn, 83 Va. 227, 2 S.E. 33 (1887); Chapman v. Chapman, 91 Va. 397, 21 S.E. 813 (1895); Hunton v. Wood, 101 Va. 54, 43 S.E. 186 (1903); Steinman v. Clinchfield Coal Corp., 121 Va. 611, 93 S.E. 684 (1917); Moore v. Postal Tel. Cable Co., 3 Va. L. Reg. (n.s.) 111 (1917). See also Price v. Wall's Ex'r, 97 Va. 334, 33 S.E. 599 (1899).

A prior unrecorded deed from his vendor does not affect the rights of a purchaser, without notice, where his vendor appears, by the records of the county where the land lies, to be the legal owner thereof. Massie v. Greenhow's Adm'r, 2 Pat. & H. 255 (1856).

In a debtor's Chapter 7 proceeding, the debtor's former spouse's motion to dismiss the trustee's complaint seeking to sell the debtor's one-half interest in real property jointly owned by the debtor and his former spouse was denied because, if there was a constructive trust on the property for the former spouse's benefit, the trustee's bona fide purchaser without notice rights allowed him to take free from the constructive trust pursuant § 55-96, and protected him against any transfer embodied in the debtor's and former spouse's unrecorded property settlement agreement pursuant to § 20-107.3. Peyton v. Robinson (In re Robinson), 346 Bankr. 172, 2006 Bankr. LEXIS 1545 (Bankr. E.D. Va. 2006).

There was nothing out of the ordinary with recorded release of 2006 deed of trust such that purchaser would have been put on constructive notice of creditors' interest in debtors' real property. Beskin v. Bank of N.Y. Mellon (In re Perrow), 498 Bankr. 560, 2013 Bankr. LEXIS 3757 (Bankr. W.D. Va. 2013).

Purchasers with notice. - Purchasers who take with actual notice of a prior deed or encumbrance upon the property take subject to such deed or conveyance, though unrecorded.
